record.text: I love teaching about the Rock of Chickamauga and Robert Smalls. Two Southerners who chose to fight for the Union and emancipation and civil rights. Being from the South didn't mean you had to be a Confederate. It was a choice. And some folks chose wrong (Robert E. Lee).

Also the financial and social investment the Slave Power had in keeping slavery around. Secessionists (and Copperheads) believed the logical conclusion of emancipation was a genocidal race war where either Whites or Blacks would be exterminated.

value.text: much easier to understand the sheer bloody intensity of the civil war when you have a good grasp on just how terrible slavery was.
"How bad slavery was" is worse. Much worse.  Much worse than you think, much worse than you're taught, much worse than museums depict. Worse.

record.text:
It's tough out here being a historian because so many people think they're a historian too just because they like reading history books... or Wikipedia pages... or now ChatGPT summaries.

How come nobody purports to be an astronomer simply because they like looking at the night sky?

Did you know ChatGPT was trained on a huge amount of data from the internet? It's not just books, but everything from Wikipedia to web pages! Let's explore how this helps ChatGPT answer so many questions.

Did you know one woman and one AI changed history forever? In 1997, IBM's supercomputer, Deep Blue, beat chess world champion Garry Kasparov! This was the first time a machine conquered a human in a chess tournament, sparking an AI revolution.

Did you know one Google AI can predict floods days in advance? It uses satellite data and can warn people early to save lives. Thanks to AI, communities get hours or even days of preparation time against rising waters.

record.text: Umbra research!

Climate activists cannot figure out that Planned Obsolescence necessitates unnecessary manufacturing which of course produces more CO2?

But economists add the junk to GDP while ignoring the depreciation. Curiously economists do not talk about the Net Domestic Product.

images.alt:
There were 200,000,000 motor vehicles in the United States in 1995. How many are operational today? Where is the Annual Demand Side Depreciation Data for the US since Sputnik?

What is Net Domestic Product?

NDP = GDP - Depreciation 

But that Depreciation is Dcap, Capital Goods only.

Economists might be able to come up with reasonable numbers for cars if they tried because of all of the state DMVs. But refrigerators, televisions, all Durable Consumer Goods? What about for the entire planet?

But NO!

All of the Demand Side Depreciation for every country on the planet can just be ignored for 70 years.

No problemo!

How does Planned Obsolescence affect the planet and the economy?

Maybe it should be:

NDP = GDP - (Dcap + Dcon)

Dcon is Depreciation of Durable Consumer Goods 

It is just a simple Algebra problem.

The Laws of Physics do not care about the difference between Capital and Consumer Goods.

Ask an Economist!

Ask ChatGPT!

The road to serfdom is paved with BMWs.

Ok, a lot of people do not like #ai for a wide variety of reasons.

Some of those reasons include decreased traffic to thier website(s).

Today that’s what I did. I asked ChatGPT (Gemini would be the same) how to fix my kindle app which had mysteriously dropped the collection from~780 books.

Fixed!

Today I asked ChatGPT:

Bc it’s really “all the things I didn’t want to have to wade through google results to figure out”

And
“I don’t care, really, if the answer is sort of wrong.”

“Today’s random question: when you wash your face are you killing a bunch of skin mites?”

#ai

(A by the way: no)

Today I had #ai look at my raised bed garden plans and help me balance out the browns (our log pile) and the greens (composted manure) and the Neutrals(soil).

And confirm that “worm casings” are indeed bags of worm poop.

It’s like google but it does the math for you.  (ChatGPT)

images.alt:
•	Garden Soil (for in-ground use): 2 bags (40 lbs each)
	•	Manure Compost: 2 bags (40 lbs each)
	•	Topsoil: 1 bag (40 lbs)
	•	Lawn Soil: 1 bag (40 lbs, this is the extra you added)
	•	Worm Castings (Elm Dirt): 1 small bag (2 lbs)

Balance Check
	•	Right now, you’ve got about 120 lbs of “soil” (garden + topsoil + lawn) and 80 lbs of composted material (manure), plus a small boost from the worm castings.
	•	That means the ratio is roughly 60% soil to 40% compost/manure, which is a lot better balanced than before (your earlier cart leaned much heavier on compost).

The extra bag of lawn soil is doing the job of pulling the mix back toward a better balance. For raised beds, you’re usually aiming at something like 1/3 compost, 2/3 soil mix. You’re now close to that — especially considering the logs and greens/browns underneath will break down and add fertility.

👉 I’d say you’re good to go with this cart. If you wanted to make it even more soil-heavy, you could throw in one more bag of topsoil, but you don’t strictly need to.

images.alt:
captura de pantalla de una tabla sobre
Posibilidades y limitaciones de ChatGPT en Educación

Posibilidades  

1. Mejorar la atención individualizada del alumnado
2. Desarrollar el aprendizaje autónomo del alumnado
3. Fomentar la participación del alumnado
4. Proporcionar retroalimentación y apoyo continuo al alumnado
5. Ayudar al profesorado en la preparación de las clases
6. Reducir la carga de trabajo del profesorado y liberar tiempo para centrarse en otros aspectos de la enseñanza
7. Analizar ensayos, trabajos escritos y respuestas a preguntas abiertas
8. Crear recursos educativos digitales e interactivos

Limitaciones

1. Necesidad de entrenamiento adecuado
2.  Necesidad de actualización constante
3. Limitaciones en la comprensión de temáticas o conceptos muy específicos

value.text: i.e. I don't think we're helping our readers by describing an LLM as "thinking" or "believing" something. I think these are often inadvertent tics/shorthand for commonsense understandings of how computers work ("the printer said it's out of ink!"), but the stakes are much much higher now.

record.text: Endorse.

value.text: Relatedly I think journalism could maybe use stronger professional style norms around not anthropomorphizing the computer systems we report on/reference in our writing.

My all-purpose AI reform is banning computers from pretending they are human. Having names, saying "I," pretending to have feelings, representing what they emit as "advice," etc. That's where much of the mischief starts.

external.description: Former President Donald Trump, who served as the 47th President of the United States during his second term starting January 20, 2025, has claimed to have ended seven wars in the first six months of his presidency. These claims have been widely debated, with various sources indicating that while some conflicts saw temporary ceasefires or diplomatic agreements, the resolutions are often not permanent, and in some cases, U.S. involvement is unclear or overstated. Below is an analysis of the seven conflicts Trump has referenced, based on available information from web sources, with a critical examination of the claims:  Israel and Iran:    Claim: Trump claimed to have ended a 12-day conflict between Israel and Iran, notably through U.S. intervention following Israel's surprise attack on Iranian nuclear facilities in June 2025. He stated that U.S. strikes "obliterated" Iran's nuclear capabilities, leading to an informal truce.    Reality: The U.S. did participate in strikes against Iranian nuclear sites (Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan) after Israel's initial attack. However, experts note there is no evidence Trump personally negotiated a ceasefire, and the truce has been violated multiple times, with ongoing tensions dating back to Iran's 1979 Islamic Revolution. The conflict is described as a "slow-boiling state of war" rather than fully resolved.  Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Rwanda:    Claim: Trump highlighted a U.S.-brokered peace deal signed on June 27, 2025, in Washington, D.C., to end fighting in eastern DRC, particularly involving Rwanda-backed M23 rebels. He called it a "glorious triumph."    Reality: The agreement was signed, but Congolese President Félix Tshisekedi claimed the diplomatic success as his own. The deal also included U.S. investment in DRC’s mineral reserves, suggesting economic motives. The conflict, ongoing for decades, has not been permanently resolved, and fighting has resumed in some areas.  Cambodia and Thailand:    Claim: Trump claimed to have ended a border conflict that erupted in early August 2025, with a truce following a phone call he made. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet nominated Trump for a Nobel Peace Prize for this.    Reality: A truce was achieved, but there is little evidence of a permanent resolution. The conflict’s specifics are vague, and the truce may be temporary, as border disputes between the two nations have historically flared up.  India and Pakistan:    Claim: Trump stated he mediated a ceasefire in May 2025, averting a "possible nuclear disaster" after planes were shot down and tensions escalated.    Reality: Pakistan acknowledged Trump’s role and supported his Nobel Peace Prize nomination, but India issued conflicting statements, denying significant U.S. involvement. The ceasefire is described as "full and immediate," but long-standing tensions, particularly over Kashmir, persist, and no permanent peace agreement exists.  Serbia and Kosovo:    Claim: Trump included this conflict in his list of resolved wars, citing diplomatic efforts to reduce hostilities.    Reality: While Trump referenced a deal, possibly building on his first-term Kosovo-Serbia agreement (2020), sources indicate no new peace treaty was signed in 2025. Tensions remain, and Serbia’s President Vučić stated in July 2025 that actions were coordinated with the U.S. and China, not solely Trump’s initiative. The conflict is far from permanently resolved.  Egypt and Ethiopia:    Claim: Trump claimed to have resolved disputes, likely related to the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) on the Nile River.    Reality: No formal agreement was signed in 2025, and Trump’s controversial remarks on the GERD project escalated tensions rather than resolved them. Ethiopia criticized his statements as "reckless." The conflict remains ongoing, with no clear evidence of U.S.-brokered peace.  Armenia and Azerbaijan:    Claim: Trump hosted leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan at the White House in August 2025, where they signed a joint declaration to advance peace over the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. He claimed this as a significant step toward ending a decades-long war.    Reality: The declaration was not a full peace deal but a commitment toward one, the first significant step since the late 1980s. Both leaders praised Trump, but the conflict, rooted in ethnic and territorial disputes, has not been fully resolved, and fighting could resume.  Critical Analysis: Exaggeration and Lack of Permanence: Trump’s claims of "ending" these wars are often overstated. Many of the agreements are temporary ceasefires or partial deals, not permanent resolutions to long-standing conflicts. For example, the Israel-Iran truce is fragile, and the DRC-Rwanda deal has seen violations. U.S. Involvement: In some cases, like India-Pakistan and Egypt-Ethiopia, there is little evidence of direct U.S. intervention or Trump’s personal role in negotiations. His administration often leverages U.S. military or economic pressure, but this does not always translate to lasting peace. Seventh War Ambiguity: Trump’s shift from claiming six to seven wars resolved (noted on August 19, 2025, during a Fox & Friends interview) lacks clarity, as the White House did not specify the seventh conflict. Some sources suggest it may include first-term achievements like the Abraham Accords, but these are unrelated to 2025. Ongoing Conflicts: Trump’s failure to resolve the Russia-Ukraine and Israel-Hamas wars, despite campaign promises to end them quickly, undercuts his "peacemaker-in-chief" narrative. These conflicts remain active, with Ukraine talks stalling and Gaza negotiations in limbo.  Conclusion: Donald Trump has claimed to have ended seven wars: Israel-Iran, DRC-Rwanda, Cambodia-Thailand, India-Pakistan, Serbia-Kosovo, Egypt-Ethiopia, and Armenia-Azerbaijan. While he has facilitated temporary agreements or ceasefires in some cases (e.g., Armenia-Azerbaijan, DRC-Rwanda), the conflicts are not permanently resolved, and his role is often overstated or disputed (e.g., Egypt-Ethiopia, Serbia-Kosovo). The seventh war remains unspecified, and ongoing major conflicts like Ukraine and Gaza highlight the limits of his claims. For a deeper understanding, cross-referencing primary sources and international reports is recommended, as the establishment narrative may amplify or downplay Trump’s role depending on political leanings.

The conflict remains ongoing, with no clear evidence of U.S.-brokered peace.  Armenia and Azerbaijan:    Claim: Trump hosted leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan at the White House in August 2025, where they signed a joint declaration to advance peace over the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict. He claimed this as a significant step toward ending a decades-long war.    Reality: The declaration was not a full peace deal but a commitment toward one, the first significant step since the late 1980s. Both leaders praised Trump, but the conflict, rooted in ethnic and territorial disputes, has not been fully resolved, and fighting could resume.  Critical Analysis: Exaggeration and Lack of Permanence: Trump’s claims of "ending" these wars are often overstated. Many of the agreements are temporary ceasefires or partial deals, not permanent resolutions to long-standing conflicts. For example, the Israel-Iran truce is fragile, and the DRC-Rwanda deal has seen violations. U.S. Involvement: In some cases, like India-Pakistan and Egypt-Ethiopia, there is little evidence of direct U.S. intervention or Trump’s personal role in negotiations. His administration often leverages U.S. military or economic pressure, but this does not always translate to lasting peace. Seventh War Ambiguity: Trump’s shift from claiming six to seven wars resolved (noted on August 19, 2025, during a Fox & Friends interview) lacks clarity, as the White House did not specify the seventh conflict. Some sources suggest it may include first-term achievements like the Abraham Accords, but these are unrelated to 2025. Ongoing Conflicts: Trump’s failure to resolve the Russia-Ukraine and Israel-Hamas wars, despite campaign promises to end them quickly, undercuts his "peacemaker-in-chief" narrative. These conflicts remain active, with Ukraine talks stalling and Gaza negotiations in limbo.  Conclusion: Donald Trump has claimed to have ended seven wars: Israel-Iran, DRC-Rwanda, Cambodia-Thailand, India-Pakistan, Serbia-Kosovo, Egypt-Ethiopia, and Armenia-Azerbaijan. While he has facilitated temporary agreements or ceasefires in some cases (e.g., Armenia-Azerbaijan, DRC-Rwanda), the conflicts are not permanently resolved, and his role is often overstated or disputed (e.g., Egypt-Ethiopia, Serbia-Kosovo). The seventh war remains unspecified, and ongoing major conflicts like Ukraine and Gaza highlight the limits of his claims. For a deeper understanding, cross-referencing primary sources and international reports is recommended, as the establishment narrative may amplify or downplay Trump’s role depending on political leanings.

record.text: If you find #GitHub #Copilot interrupts your flow while writing code in #VisualStudio, you can now disable it. Go to Tools → Options → IntelliCode → General → Automatically generate code completions in the Editor and uncheck it. Instead, use Alt+, or Alt+. to generate code completions on demand.

Microsoft Excel adds Copilot Al to help ...
theverge.com
The Verget-4.1-mini Al model | 5
successor to the LABS.GENERATIVEAI function Microsoft started experimenting
with in 2023.
Microsoft notes that you can combine its new Al function with other Excel functions, including IF, SWITCH, LAMBDA, or WRAPROWS. The company adds that information sent through Excel's COPILOT function is "never" used for AI training, as "the input remains confidential and is used solely to generate your requested output."
The COPILOT function comes with a couple of limitations, as it can't access information outside your spreadsheet, and you can only use it to calculate 100 functions every 10 minutes. Microsoft also warns against using the AI function for numerical calculations or in “high-stakes scenarios” with legal, regulatory, and compliance implications, as COPILOT "can
give incorrect responses."

So up until a year ago, every customer product facing cloud vuln they fixed wasn’t disclosed to customers - and yes, there are dead bodies in cupboards over that. Everything wasn’t magic immune from vulns until a year ago.

The progress here is they now opt to disclose cloud critical vulns - but nothing below that severity, which is a lot.

To give MS their credit, they’re the only cloud provider I’ve seen disclosing any cloud service vulns via CVE.

record.text: Stories about AI (“AI”) read more clearly if you mentally add air quotes around almost every noun and verb

value.text: i.e. I don't think we're helping our readers by describing an LLM as "thinking" or "believing" something. I think these are often inadvertent tics/shorthand for commonsense understandings of how computers work ("the printer said it's out of ink!"), but the stakes are much much higher now.

record.text: Relatedly I think journalism could maybe use stronger professional style norms around not anthropomorphizing the computer systems we report on/reference in our writing.

value.text: My all-purpose AI reform is banning computers from pretending they are human. Having names, saying "I," pretending to have feelings, representing what they emit as "advice," etc. That's where much of the mischief starts.
